paragraphs.text: Chaplain punished for sharing his faith in suicide prevention class.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: An Army chaplain was punished for discussing matters of faith and quoting from the Bible during a suicide prevention training session with the 5th Ranger Training Battalion -- leading to outrage from religious liberty groups and a Georgia congressman
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Chaplain Joseph Lawhorn was issued a Letter of Concern that accused him of advocating for Christianity and "using Christian scripture and solutions" during a Nov  20th training session held at the University of North Georgia
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "You provided a two-sided handout that listed Army resources on one side and a biblical approach to handling depression on the other side," Col  David Fivecoat, the commander of the Airborne and Ranger Training Brigade at Ft  Benning, Georgia, wrote in the letter to the chaplain
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "This made it impossible for those in attendance to receive the resource information without also receiving the biblical information."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The Christian chaplain was warned to be "careful to avoid any perception you are advocating one system of beliefs over another."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: attorneys for the chaplain, along with religious advocacy groups, say his comments are covered by the "right of conscience clause" that was passed in last year's National Defense Authorization Act, section 533
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Chaplain Lawhorn was ordered to appear in the colonel's office on Thanksgiving Day where he was personally handed the Letter of Concern
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Based on Col  Fivecoat's version of events -- you would've thought Chaplain Lawhorn had turned the suicide prevention workshop into a Billy Graham Crusade
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that's not what happened
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: During the course of
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: conducting the training session
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Ron Crews, the endorsing agent for military chaplains for Grace Churches International, explained, the chaplain discussed his own struggles with depression and the methods and techniques he personally used to combat depression
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He said the chaplain did provide a handout with religious resources
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: but he also provided a handout with non-religious resources
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "The chaplain did nothing wrong," said Crews
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "At no time did he say his was the only or even the preferred way of dealing with depression. And at no time did he deny the validity of any other method."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Lawhorn is one of the few Army chaplains to wear the Ranger Tab
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Crews said it was through that identification that he shared his story about depression
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "His story involves his faith journey," Crews said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "He was simply being a great Army chaplain - in ministering to his troops and providing first hand how he has dealt with depression in the past
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: That's what chaplains do. They bare their souls for their soldiers in order to help them with crises they may be going through."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: someone in the training session complained to the Military Association of Atheists and Freethinkers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: That complaint led to a story on the Huffington Post
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Michael Berry, an attorney with Liberty Institute, a law firm that handles religious liberty cases, is representing the chaplain
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He said the person who filed the complained "exploited" the chaplain's "vulnerability."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "It took a great amount of courage for Chaplain Lawhorn to discuss his own personal battle with depression," Berry said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "At no time did he consider himself to be in a 'preacher' role."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Berry called on the Army to rescind the Letter of Concern-- calling it a violation of the chaplain's constitutional rights
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Not only is it lawful for a chaplain to talk about matters of faith and spirituality and religion in a suicide prevention training class- but the Army policy encourages discussion of matters of faith and spiritual wellness," Berry told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "The fact that one person in the class was offended changes nothing."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Congressman Doug Collins, a Republican lawmaker from Georgia, whose district includes the area where the training session took place, fired off a letter to Col  Fivecoat expressing his concerns in the matter
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "I find it counterintuitive to have someone lead a suicide prevention course but prohibit them from providing their personal testimony," Collins wrote
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He cited the Army's Equal Opportunity policy and how it was set up to protect the personal beliefs of military personnel
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "I fear Chaplain Lawhorn's freedom of expression was improperly singled out," he wrote
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Liberty Institute tells me the Army will allow me to speak with the chaplain -- but not right now
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: And Col  Fivecoat sent me an email telling me that he would not be able to comment at this point
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: If I'm reading between the lines -- that Letter of Concern comes pretty close to accusing the chaplain of proselytizing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Crews agrees with my assessment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "The bottom line is -- that is exactly what they are trying to accuse him of-- when nothing could be further from the truth," Crews told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "The military leadership needs to commend Chaplain Lawhorn, not condemn him."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Berry said Americans should be shocked and outraged over Chaplain Lawhorn's punishment
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "His job is to save lives-- and he's being punished for trying to do his job," Berry said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "He's doing everything he can to save them- and yet now they're trying to say - the way you're doing it offends me."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: I find it both repulsive and heartbreaking to know that we have a military that frowns upon a chaplain using a Bible to save a soldier's life
paragraphs.label: assumption
